Hi Sebastian,

I'm glad you found it interesting :). Answers to your questi=
ons inline
below.

On 1 May 2014 03:14, Sebastian Risi <sebastian.risi@gmai=
l.com> wrote:
>
>>
>>
>> Hi Oliver and Jeff,
>>
>> Very interesting paper! =
Good to see that more and more people are working
>> on plastic ANNs!
>>
>>=
 I also had one question about the CPPN outputs that determine the type of
=
>> plasticity. In our original adaptive HyperNEAT paper (Risi&Stanley, 2010=
)
>> the CPPN directly specifies the values for the parameters of Niv's
>> =
equation.  Did you also try this approach or why did you decide to limit
>>=
 the number of possible rules to four?
>>
>
Yes, we did some preliminary ex=
periments where the parameters for the
plasticity rule were set directly by=
 CPPN outputs and, if I remember
correctly, this at least didn't perform an=
y better than using four evolved
rules. I like the idea of the limited numb=
er of evolved rules so I decided
to use that approach.


> In your paper yo=
u
>> compare it to Ken's paper on adaptive NEAT and say that "Two benefits =
of
>> this approach are that it reduces the overall search space...". But I=
 think
>> there is a difference here when we are talking about a direct (NE=
AT) or an
>> indirect encoding (HyperNEAT).
>>
>
I agree, this isn't necess=
arily a straight comparison. HyperNEAT transforms
the search space in a way=
 that, while it doesn't necessarily limit the
number of connection rules/si=
ze of the search space, it does make it more
likely to produce certain patt=
erns of rules which at least works well for
some problem domains if not mos=
t. Perhaps a finite set of evolved rules
will work better in some domains a=
nd CPPN encoded parameters will work
better in others?

Cheers,
Oliver


>
=
>> This is the paper on Adaptive HyperNEAT I was referring to:
>> Sebastian=
 Risi and Kenneth O. Stanley (2010) Indirectly Encoding Neural
>> Plasticit=
y as a Pattern of Local Rules In: Proceedings of the 11th
>> International =
Conference on Simulation of Adaptive Behavior (SAB 2010). New
>> York, NY: =
Springer.
>> PDF: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_sab10.pdf
>>
>> Sebas=
tian
>>
>
>>
>>
>>
>> On Wed, Apr 30, 2014 at 6:56 PM, Jeff Clune <jclune@g=
mail.com> wrote:
>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Yes, it is clear now. I guess one could=
 also encode the mutation rates
>>> in the genotype, like in Evolution Stra=
tegies, and make these parameters
>>> self-adaptive.
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Self-a=
daptive mutation rates are a terrible idea! Please read this for
>>> an exp=
lanation:
>>>
>>> Clune J, Misevic D, Ofria C, Lenski RE, Elena SF, and San=
ju=C3=A1n R (2008)
>>> Natural selection fails to optimize mutation rates f=
or long-term
>>> adaptation on rugged fitness landscapes. PLoS Computationa=
l Biology 4(9):
>>> e1000187.
>>> pdf:
>>> http://jeffclune.com/publication=
s/Clune-EvolvingMutationRates-PLoSCB-2008.pdf
>>>
>>> I have spent years as=
king anyone I encounter who advocates self-adaptive
>>> mutation rates for =
evidence that they work, or even an argument as to why
>>> they could work,=
 and all those conversations have come up empty. Mostly I
>>> end up convin=
cing them that self-adaptive mutation rates are a bad idea, or
>>> they end=
 up defending something other than self-adaptive mutation rates
>>> (e.g. R=
echenberg=E2=80=99s 1/5th rule, which is not an example of a self adaptive
=
>>> mutation rate: it=E2=80=99s an externally controlled schedule).
>>>
>>>=
 For some reason people believe they are a good idea, but without
>>> evide=
nce or intuition. I=E2=80=99m constantly surprised at how persistent this
>=
>> errant belief is. I think it=E2=80=99s because ultimately we want to bel=
ieve that
>>> evolution is good at optimizing everything, and we don=E2=80=
=99t want to have to
>>> set parameters, so we feel like we should just tur=
n them over to evolution.
>>> But we have lots of evidence of evolution bei=
ng short-sighted (e.g. it
>>> doesn=E2=80=99t evolve modularity when it wou=
ld help: http://goo.gl/2vzFv).
>>>
>>> Sorry to jump on your side comment o=
n this issue, but I=E2=80=99m trying to
>>> spread the word in the communit=
y that self-adaptive mutation rates do not
>>> work.
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> If I r=
emember correctly when reading Soltoggio's paper, he used some
>>> constrai=
nts when evolving the parameters of the plasticity rule and
>>> specificall=
y, A-D were in the range [-1,1] and eta in the range [-100,100].
>>> Did yo=
u use any similar constraints?
>>>
>>> Just out of curiosity, what activati=
on function did you use for these
>>> n+1 outputs that correspond to the cl=
asses? Did you use a softmax
>>> activation function to interpret the outpu=
ts as a probability distribution
>>> (and consequently selected the class p=
robabilistically) or did you just
>>> select the class based on the highest=
 output among these neurons?
>>>
>>>
>>>  The number of states is independe=
nt of the number of actions.
>>>> Different actions in state A may all lead=
 to state B but provide different
>>>> reward values.
>>>>
>>>
>>> So, how =
many states did you use for your simulations? Is it 4 (like in
>>> Figure 1=
)? I might have missed that when reading the paper, this is why I
>>> asked=
 whether the number of actions correspond to the number of states.
>>>
>>>
=
>>>
>>>>  3) On page 3 you say that "the proportion of state transitions th=
at
>>>>> provide a reward value is 0.5". It is not clear to me, however, wh=
at the
>>>>> reward values are. Do all transitions that have a reward value=
 have the
>>>>> *same* reward value (e.g. equal to 1), or does this value v=
ary?
>>>>>
>>>>
>>>> For transitions that provide a reward, the reward is s=
elected uniformly
>>>> from the range [0, 1).
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>> Also, r=
egarding the "maximum possible reward maxRx", do you mean the
>>>>> "return=
 (sum of rewards) obtained by the optimal policy"? If you have the
>>>>> *s=
ame* reward value on the transitions (as mentioned above) then it is easy
>=
>>>> to calculate maxRx; if the reward values vary then I guess you have to=

>>>>> calculate maxRx using dynamic programming; the initial state and the=
 trial
>>>>> length matters, especially in the case where you have 16 actio=
ns (states?)
>>>>> and trial length =3D 4.
>>>>>
>>>>
>>>> Because the leng=
th of trials is relatively small (and the MDPs
>>>> deterministic) we calcu=
late the maximum return via a simple brute force
>>>> method that tries eve=
ry possible sequence of actions for the specific trial
>>>> length in quest=
ion.
>>>>
>>>
>>> Ok, it's clear now.
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>> Yes, this is an inte=
resting question in general, and certainly previous
>>>> results on simple =
deceptive domains indicate that for delayed-reward MDP
>>>> environments li=
ke you describe (neuro)evolution will likely get stuck if
>>>> the search i=
sn't aided by something like Novelty Search. In our paper we
>>>> don't wor=
ry about this issue as we are comparing the performance of the
>>>> differe=
nt neural network models relative to each other and are not
>>>> particular=
ly interested in their performance relative to the maximum
>>>> possible (w=
e do scale the results relative to the maximum possible but this
>>>> is si=
mply to make aggregation of results easier).
>>>>
>>>
>>> One issue at a ti=
me :)
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>
>>
>> --
>> Dr. Sebastian Risi
>> Assistant Profes=
sor
>> IT University of Copenhagen, Room 5D08
>> Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 230=
0 Copenhagen, Denmark
>> email: sebastian.risi@..., web: www.sebastia=
nrisi.com
>> mobile: +45-50250355, office: +45-7218-5127
>>
>>  
>>
>
>

><div style=3D"font-family:Times-Roman">I have spent years asking anyone I =

ations have come up empty. Mostly I end up convincing them that self-adapti=
ve mutation rates are a bad idea, or they end up defending something other =
than self-adaptive mutation rates (e.g. Rechenberg=E2=80=99s 1/5th rule, wh=
ich is not an example of a self adaptive mutation rate: it=E2=80=99s an ext=
ernally controlled schedule).=C2=A0</div>

ople believe they are a good idea, but without evidence or intuition. I=E2=
=80=99m constantly surprised at how persistent this errant belief is. I thi=

d at optimizing everything, and we don=E2=80=99t want to have to set parame=
ters, so we feel like we should just turn them over to evolution. But we ha=
ve lots of evidence of evolution being short-sighted (e.g. it doesn=E2=80=

</div></div></div></blockquote><div><br></div><d=
iv>Ok, it's clear now.</div><div><br></div><div>=C2=A0=C2=A0</div><bloc=
kquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0px 0px 0px 0.8ex;border-left-=
width:1px;border-left-color:rgb(204,204,204);border-left-style:solid">




=
<div><div dir=3D"ltr"><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><div class=3D"gmail_quote"=
><div>Yes, this is an interesting question in general, and certainly previo=
us results on simple deceptive domains indicate that for delayed-reward MDP=
 environments like you describe (neuro)evolution will likely get stuck if t=
he search isn't aided by something like Novelty Search. In our paper we=
 don't worry about this issue as we are comparing the performance of th=
e different neural network models relative to each other and are not partic=
ularly interested in their performance relative to the maximum possible (we=
 do scale the results relative to the maximum possible but this is simply t=
o make aggregation of results easier).</div>




</div></div></div></div></=
blockquote><div><br></div><div>One issue at a time :)</div><div><br></div><=
/div></div></div></div></div><div><br></div>

    </div>
     

    

</div=
>





</div></div></blockquote></div></div><br><p></p>
